name: Policy placement guide (baseline conventions)
description: A practical baseline for where to place policies and how to keep them maintainable across many APIs.
decision: What goes at global scope vs product vs API vs operation, and what conventions prevent duplication and drift?
whyItMatters: A stable placement model enables predictable behavior and easier audits.
Scope conventions prevent double application of throttles, headers, and auth rules.
Clear conventions improve onboarding for new engineers and reduce incident risk.
checklist: Global: minimal defaults only (base, correlation headers if safe, shared logging guardrails).
Product: usage governance and consumer controls (quota/rate-limit), consistent across a consumer tier.
API: API-specific auth requirements, routing conventions, backend mapping.
Operation: exceptional cases only (rare overrides, operation-specific validation).
Use named values for environment-specific configuration and avoid hardcoding secrets in policy XML.
validation: Pick one API and verify which scopes contain which policies (document the standard).
Confirm no duplicate throttles or duplicate auth validation across scopes.
Confirm policies are testable and changes have rollback steps.
pitfalls: Global policies become a dumping ground (hard to test and audit).
Operation-level policies become widespread (too much divergence).
Policy changes in production without a staging revision or targeted validation.
